path_1.title: Speed 2: Cruise Control (1997)
path_1.feeling: A dull, implausible sequel that lacks urgency or chemistry and just wore me down.

path_1.title: Hercules (1997)
path_1.feeling: Light, funny, and tuneful enough to win me over even if it’s not Pixar-level.

path_1.title: For the Birds (2000)
path_1.feeling: A perfect, punchy Pixar short with impeccable timing and a sweet sting.

path_1.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Cute in spots but mostly broad, repetitive kid gags that didn’t land for me.

path_1.title: Chicago (2002)
path_1.feeling: Slick, catchy, and sharply staged—an energetic musical with bite.

path_1.title: Kiss the Girls (1997)
path_1.feeling: A solid, tense procedural with good leads, even if it plays familiar beats.

path_1.title: JFK (1991)
path_1.feeling: Dense, riveting, and skillfully constructed

path_1.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_1.feeling: Moody and atmospheric with a compelling mystery, though the scares linger more than the story.

path_1.title: South Pacific (1958)
path_1.feeling: Classic songs and old-fashioned romance I enjoyed, despite the dated pacing.

path_1.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_1.feeling: A masterfully grim, engrossing thriller that sticks with me.

path_1.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_1.feeling: Handsome but ponderous and schmaltzy to the point of testing my patience.

path_1.title: Crush, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Glossy but trashy thriller that thrills in moments and is predictable otherwise.

path_1.title: Dave (1993)
path_1.feeling: Warm, witty, and good-hearted, if a bit soft around the edges.

path_1.title: Mrs. Doubtfire (1993)
path_1.feeling: A big-hearted family comedy with enough laughs and warmth to work.

path_1.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_1.feeling: Smart, quietly gripping, and morally tangled in all the right ways.

path_1.title: Lucas (1986)
path_1.feeling: A tender, awkward coming-of-age story that feels honest if modest.

path_1.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Sweet but thin, with slapstick that wears out before the charm does.

path_1.title: Howard the Duck (1986)
path_1.feeling: Goofy and grating more often than fun, with humor that largely misses me.

path_1.title: Adventures in Babysitting (1987)
path_1.feeling: A breezy, likable 80s romp with enough scrapes and laughs to entertain.

path_1.title: Birdcage, The (1996)
path_1.feeling: Fast, funny farce anchored by delightful performances and sharp comic timing.

path_1.title: Tangled (2010)
path_1.feeling: Lively, funny, and sweet with catchy songs and appealing animation.

path_1.title: Office Space (1999)
path_1.feeling: Dry, incisive workplace satire that hits close to home and stays funny.

path_1.title: Batman (1989)
path_1.feeling: Moody and stylish with a memorable villain and strong atmosphere.

path_1.title: Brady Bunch Movie, The (1995)
path_1.feeling: The gag stays cute but one-note, amusing in small doses.

path_1.title: Planet of the Apes (2001)
path_1.feeling: Slick but hollow sci-fi adventure that left me unmoved.

path_1.title: Courage Under Fire (1996)
path_1.feeling: Well-acted, thoughtful investigation drama with satisfying revelations.

path_1.title: Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot (1992)
path_1.feeling: Shrill, clunky, and rarely funny—definitely not my kind of action-comedy.

path_1.title: Falling Down (1993)
path_1.feeling: A compelling, uncomfortable character spiral that kept me tense and conflicted.

path_1.title: Toy Story Toons: Small Fry (2011)
path_1.feeling: Clever, brisk, and funny—another irresistible Toy Story short.

path_1.title: Guardians of the Galaxy (2014)
path_1.feeling: A fizzy, fun space romp with great banter and a killer vibe.

path_2.title: Speed 2: Cruise Control (1997)
path_2.feeling: Clunky, stakes feel silly, and the thrills never click for me.

path_2.title: Hercules (1997)
path_2.feeling: Fun songs and Hades’ antics, but it’s mid‑tier Disney for me.

path_2.title: For the Birds (2000)
path_2.feeling: Clever, brisk visual gag machine with a perfect punchline I love.

path_2.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Cute but too cutesy and sketchy to really land for me.

path_2.title: Chicago (2002)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, catchy showbiz razzle‑dazzle with a sharp bite that works.

path_2.title: Kiss the Girls (1997)
path_2.feeling: Solid, moody serial‑killer procedural that keeps me engaged.

path_2.title: JFK (1991)
path_2.feeling: Absorbing, propulsive conspiracy mosaic that scratches my investigative itch.

path_2.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_2.feeling: Atmospheric and creepy mystery, but the scares dampen my enjoyment.

path_2.title: South Pacific (1958)
path_2.feeling: Classic tunes and romance, though it feels dated and uneven.

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Dark, gripping, and meticulously crafted—exactly the kind of thriller I savor.

path_2.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_2.feeling: Languid and ponderous melodrama that just doesn’t work for me.

path_2.title: Crush, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Glossy, pulpy stalker thriller that’s watchable but thin.

path_2.title: Dave (1993)
path_2.feeling: Warm, witty crowd‑pleaser with a charming premise that goes down easy.

path_2.title: Mrs. Doubtfire (1993)
path_2.feeling: Heartfelt, funny family tale with Robin Williams’ warmth winning me over.

path_2.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_2.feeling: Elegant, probing drama about deception that quietly grips me.

path_2.title: Lucas (1986)
path_2.feeling: Tender coming‑of‑age beats, modest but affecting.

path_2.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Cute but too cutesy and sketchy to really land for me.

path_2.title: Howard the Duck (1986)
path_2.feeling: Goofy, noisy misfire that wears out its welcome fast.

path_2.title: Adventures in Babysitting (1987)
path_2.feeling: Light, episodic 80s romp that’s fun enough but slight.

path_2.title: Birdcage, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Sparkling performances and generous humor with a warm, farcical heart.

path_2.title: Tangled (2010)
path_2.feeling: Buoyant, funny, and sweet with songs and heart I really enjoy.

path_2.title: Office Space (1999)
path_2.feeling: Dry, sharp workplace satire that hits a very satisfying groove.

path_2.title: Batman (1989)
path_2.feeling: Moody, stylish comic‑book noir with iconic villainy I enjoy.

path_2.title: Brady Bunch Movie, The (1995)
path_2.feeling: Cute concept, but the joke wears thin for me.

path_2.title: Planet of the Apes (2001)
path_2.feeling: Serviceable spectacle, but thin characters and awkward tone hold it back.

path_2.title: Courage Under Fire (1996)
path_2.feeling: Thoughtful, well‑acted investigation with moral weight that hooks me.

path_2.title: Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot (1992)
path_2.feeling: Broad, clunky silliness that mostly makes me wince.

path_2.title: Falling Down (1993)
path_2.feeling: Edgy, compelling urban meltdown with tension and bite.

path_2.title: Toy Story Toons: Small Fry (2011)
path_2.feeling: Cute, clever Toy Story mini that gives me a pleasant dose of playtime.

path_2.title: Guardians of the Galaxy (2014)
path_2.feeling: Zippy, witty space adventure with a big heart and great tunes.

path_2.title: Speed 2: Cruise Control (1997)
path_2.feeling: Bloated, low-tension sequel that left me seasick with boredom.

path_2.title: Hercules (1997)
path_2.feeling: Bouncy, witty Disney romp with catchy tunes, not top-tier but a fun time.

path_2.title: For the Birds (2000)
path_2.feeling: Sharp, wordless slapstick with perfect timing and a sweet sting.

path_2.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Cute and harmless with a few laughs, but pretty thin overall.

path_2.title: Chicago (2002)
path_2.feeling: Slick, snappy musical with stylish bite that goes down easy.

path_2.title: Kiss the Girls (1997)
path_2.feeling: Solid, if familiar, serial-killer hunt that kept me mildly gripped.

path_2.title: JFK (1991)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping, obsessive investigation that pulls me in even when it overreaches.

path_2.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_2.feeling: Creepy, moody mystery that got under my skin even if it’s not cozy.

path_2.title: South Pacific (1958)
path_2.feeling: Lush songs and earnest romance, a bit stagy and dated for me.

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Bleak, riveting cat-and-mouse that fires on every thriller cylinder for me.

path_2.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_2.feeling: Glacial and ponderous, a romance that never clicked.

path_2.title: Crush, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Sleekly packaged but sleazy and shallow, with little real suspense.

path_2.title: Dave (1993)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, good-hearted political fairy tale that left me smiling.

path_2.title: Mrs. Doubtfire (1993)
path_2.feeling: Warm, funny family comedy with genuine heart beneath the antics.

path_2.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_2.feeling: Smart, engrossing scandal drama with quietly gripping momentum.

path_2.title: Lucas (1986)
path_2.feeling: Tender teen heartache told with sincerity and a soft touch.

path_2.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Still cute in spots, but the charm is pretty lightweight.

path_2.title: Howard the Duck (1986)
path_2.feeling: Awkward, noisy oddity that rarely lands a laugh.

path_2.title: Adventures in Babysitting (1987)
path_2.feeling: Scrappy, charming ’80s city misadventure that goes down easy.

path_2.title: Birdcage, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Big-hearted, witty farce that made me laugh and grin.

path_2.title: Tangled (2010)

path_2.title: Office Space (1999)

path_2.title: Batman (1989)

path_2.feeling: Tense, unsettling character spiral that kept me engaged.

path_3.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Cute in spots, but the kiddie gags wore thin pretty quickly.

path_3.feeling: Slick, snappy numbers and jazzy bite kept me entertained.

path_3.title: Kiss the Girls (1997)
